steps.title: If you need to loop a definite amount of times, you need a for loop.
steps.content: If you need to loop a definite amount of times, you need a for loop. This is the structure for a for loop. The example prints "hello, world!" 10 times:

steps.title: If you need something to loop forever, or until a condition is met, you need a while loop.
steps.content: If you need something to loop forever, or until a condition is met, you need a while loop. A method for both is shown. That will throw a SyntaxError unless you use Python version 2. It is recommended to use the above example of the print statement.

steps.title: This will loop forever, or until the program ends.
steps.content: This will loop forever, or until the program ends. In this example, True will always be True as long as the variable's answer and grade are Yes and 6. If they never changed, it will run forever so the while loop just makes the code loop while something is happening.

steps.title: If you need to stop a loop while it's running in the terminal, use Ctrl+C.
steps.content: If you need to stop a loop while it's running in the terminal, use Ctrl+C . You can always kill the loop in Task Manager as well. The other way is using the break command or using while loops.

steps.title: If you need to stop a loop inside the program, use break.
steps.content: If you need to stop a loop inside the program, use break .
